title: 113_hr3308
content:
The "Taxpayer Transparency Act of 2014" requires federal agencies to adhere to specific guidelines for printed materials and advertisements. The "Taxpayer Transparency Act of 2014" mandates that all federally funded communications must clearly disclose that they are printed or produced at taxpayer expense. This applies to advertisements and information about federal programs, benefits, or services. The "Taxpayer Transparency Act of 2014" requires federally funded communications to clearly disclose that they are printed or produced at taxpayer expense. The communication must have a readable statement in a printed box with color contrast for visibility. Audio and video communications must also include spoken or visual disclosures as necessary. Any e-mail communication described in subsection (a)(2) must include a statement conveyed clearly through spoken or visual means, and also in writing with color contrast for at least 4 seconds. In communications described in subsection (a)(2), information must be displayed clearly with sufficient type size, set apart from other content, and have a reasonable degree of color contrast. For communications funded by user fees or non-Federal sources, Federal agencies can apply these requirements by substituting "by the". The Act defines "Federal agency" and "mass mailing" and specifies that funds used by a Federal agency must come from a specific source. The funds used by a Federal agency to carry out this Act must come from amounts allocated for advertising or providing information about Federal programs. This section applies only to communications produced after the Act's enactment date. SEC. 3. GUIDANCE FOR IMPLEMENTATION.

The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must issue guidance on implementing the requirements of this Act within 6 months of its enactment.

SEC. 4. JUDICIAL REVIEW AND ENFORCEABILITY.

There shall be no judicial review of compliance with this Act, and no provision of this Act can be enforced through administrative or judicial action.
